S4.T1.caption: Table 1: Results (way, shot) in Omniglot and miniImageNet. The ACAI/DC (RO/N) mean ACAI clustering (Random Out-of-class samples) on Omniglot and DeepCluster (Noise) on miniImageNet.
references:
Toy dataset.
The 2-way 4-shot classification results in the toy dataset are 78.51 Â±plus-or-minus\pm 0.36 for Meta-GMVAE and 93.08 Â±plus-or-minus\pm 0.32 for our CMVAE. Since Meta-GMVAE does not take into account the context-bias, its performance is not impressive. While our CMVAE notices the existence of context-bias, the about 15% improvement on the biased toy dataset demonstrates that it offers the ability to alleviate the context-bias.
Natural dataset.
Table 1 reports the results of few-shot image classification for Omniglot and miniImageNet benchmarks. Table 2 shows the results of 5-way few-shot identity recognition on CelebA. We can observe that our method outperforms state-of-the-art methods, except for the UMTRA on the 20-shot 5-shot classification in Omniglot. Our CMVAE even outperforms 5-way 1-shot classification supervised MAML in Omniglot. It is noticed that, for challenging dataset e.g., miniImageNet, our method outperforms Meta-GMVAE by more than about 2.5% average. This shows that 1) Our meta-learning network can capture the causal multi-modal distribution. 2) The causality is a more reliable in the natural images. 3) With causally independent codes and the adjustment for intervention, the confounding effect of meta-knowledge are removed.

S5.T3.caption: Table 3:  Results of 5-way 1-shot classification on Omniglot, miniImageNet and CelebA with different settings. We show the impact of choosing hyper parameters on test accuracies. In the Default, the causal function is non-linear, Î»1=1subscriptğœ†11\lambda_{1}=1, Î»2=10âˆ’4subscriptğœ†2superscript104\lambda_{2}=10^{-4}, and Î³=1ğ›¾1\gamma=1.
references: DAG type. We compare the performance of CMVAE with regard to the DAG type, i.e., when the DAG function hâ„h is linear or non-linear. The results are shown in the Rows 1-2 of Table 3. We can observe that performances get worse when the function hâ„h is linear, which is in line with the common sense that the cause-to-effect is not a simple linear but a complex non-linear relation in the natural images.

Influence of Î»1,Î»2subscriptğœ†1subscriptğœ†2\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2}. The hyper parameters Î»1,Î»2subscriptğœ†1subscriptğœ†2\lambda_{1},\lambda_{2} control the â€œDAGnessâ€. The larger Î»1subscriptğœ†1\lambda_{1} and Î»2subscriptğœ†2\lambda_{2}, the more strongly causal relations are enforced. Rows 3-8 of Table 3 show that the setting when Î»1=1,Î»2=10âˆ’4formulae-sequencesubscriptğœ†11subscriptğœ†2superscript104\lambda_{1}=1,\lambda_{2}=10^{-4} outperforms other settings. This is because in the real-world images, factors with semantics are unknown and uncountable. The weak constraints can avoid overfitting the causal relations.

Effects of Î³ğ›¾\gamma. The value of hype parameter Î³ğ›¾\gamma controls the influence of causal regularization on modalities. The last 5 rows of Table 3 shows the test class accuracies with respect to different values of Î³ğ›¾\gamma. Though Î³2=1,Î³2=5,Î³2=0.9formulae-sequencesuperscriptğ›¾21formulae-sequencesuperscriptğ›¾25superscriptğ›¾20.9\gamma^{2}=1,\gamma^{2}=5,\gamma^{2}=0.9 provide the best results for Omniglot, miniImageNet and CelebA, which shows that the causal regularization needs to satisfy for different datasets, the default value already outperforms SOTA and it is user-friendly in practice.

S5.T4.caption: Table 4: Time (s) cost over 10000 20-way tasks on Omniglot during the meta-test stage. Inverse: Matrix inversion.
references: Time complexity. Compared with the original EM, the inference of causal-EM comes with more time cost, as matrix operations (i.e., inversion) have cubic time complexity. Table 4 reports that causal-EM costs about 10% more time, which is acceptable compared to the better accuracy.

references:
Results of Each Component.
Table 12 reports the results of the ablation study on each component on 5-way 1-shot classification on miniImageNet and CelebA. â€™Baselineâ€™ denotes that we do not consider the causality and do not apply the adjusting term. â€™ATâ€™ denotes that we apply the adjusting term. â€™Linearâ€™ denotes that we assume the causality relationship between context priors is linear. â€™Nonlinearâ€™ denotes that we assume the causality relationship between context priors is nonlinear. â€™Vanilla-EMâ€™ denotes that we calculate the modalities with traditional EM. â€™Causal-EMâ€™ denotes that we calculate the modalities with causal-EM. We observe that: (1) It is in line with common sense that the cause-to-effect is not a simple linear but a complex nonlinear relationship in the natural images. (2) With nonlinear assumptions, the adjusting term address the context bias. (3) Causal-EM is the solution for maximum causal posterior and can remove the context bias better.

A5.T13.caption: Table 13: Results with 95% confidence interval on the biased toy examples.
A5.T13.table:
Method 2-way 5-shot
Meta-GMVAE 78.51 Â±plus-or-minus\pm 0.36
Ours 93.08 Â±plus-or-minus\pm 0.32
references:
Biased Toy Example.
Here we provide a 2-way biased toy example. We build a synthetic image dataset with two class â€birdâ€ and â€planeâ€. Specially, 2k images (1K for training and 1K for test) are generated by the Composable Diffusion Models (Liu etÂ al. 2022a) with the text input â€A bird in the skyâ€, â€A bird is on the groundâ€, â€A plane in the skyâ€ and â€A plane is on the groundâ€. Figure 11 shows some samples. As Figure 1 shows, in the tasks, the support sets are biased and the query sets are drawn uniformly at random. During test, the number of clusters is set to 2 and the number of query data is 15. The results are as shown in Table 13. We can observe that our can alleviate the bias with about 15% improvement.

A5.T14.caption: Table 14: Results with 95% confidence interval on the miniImageNet and CelebA.
A5.T14.table:
Method miniImageNet CelebA
DRC 43.14 Â±plus-or-minus\pm 0.73 59.67 Â±plus-or-minus\pm 0.91
STMT 41.97 Â±plus-or-minus\pm 0.65 58.92 Â±plus-or-minus\pm 0.90
Ours 44.27 Â±plus-or-minus\pm 0.76 61.04 Â±plus-or-minus\pm 0.94
references: For background removal approaches, DRC (Yu etÂ al. 2021) is probabilistic foreground-background modeling by reconciling energy-based prior in a fully unsupervised manner. For probabilistic graphical models (PGMs), STMT (Gangloff etÂ al. 2021) enriches the dependencies between the random variables to better take into account the spatial context of an image in an unsupervised manner. To apply DRC and STMT in unsupervised meta-learning, we train them in the unlabeled train set to remove the background and extract the foreground and then use standard Meta-GMVAE to perform classification. The results of 5-way 1-shot classification are as shown in Table 14. Our method performs best. The reason may be (1) DRC and STMT do not consider the dependence among priors. (2) Meta-GMVAE highly depends on the qualities of DRC and STMT.
